title: Some Tech Stocks Are Overvalued: Kraus & Tett
text: Feb.26 -- Financial Times Editorial Board Chair Gillian Tett says some tech stocks are overvalued and cautions that markets are positioned in a way that suggests that rates will stay low forever. Aperture Investors Chairman & CEO Peter Kraus agrees that some tech stocks are overvalued, but thinks innovative tech stocks will still perform well.

title: When Stocks Will Turn Up Again
text: A painful week for investors … why John Jagerson and Wade Hansen don't believe it will turn into something uglier … how much longer the weakness could last We shouldn't be worried about traders reaping some profits right now. That's how our technical experts, John Jagerson and Wade Hansen, began their Strategic Trader update from Wednesday.

title: What to Buy When Good News Means Bad News for Stocks
text: A “hot” economy will favor some sectors, not others. But the question remains whether the spike in bond yields is a hiccup or something more lasting.

title: Wall Street Week Ahead: Investors weigh new stock leadership as broader market wobbles
text: A shakeup in stocks accelerated by the past week's surge in Treasury yields has investors weighing how far a recent leadership rotation in the U.S. equity market can run, and its implications for the broader S&P 500 index.

title: Cramer's week ahead: Strong February jobs report could cause another sell-off
text: "If we get any strength here at all, any strength, please brace yourself for another tsunami of selling as interest rates go higher and stocks go lower," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Explainer: Why rising rates are unsettling Wall Street
text: Yes, it's possible to have too much of a good thing, and that's exactly why stock markets around the world are getting so unsettled. Optimism for an economic revival is surging following a year of coronavirus-induced misery.

title: Cramer's week ahead: The February jobs report will be especially crucial
text: "If we get any strength here at all, any strength, please brace yourself for another tsunami of selling as interest rates go higher and stocks go lower," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Rising Treasury Yields Signal This Rally Could Be Nearing an End
text: You don't have to doubt the Fed to be worried about the possibility of rising interest rates. All you have to do is consider the amount of money that is heading into the economy.

title: Cramer recaps tough week for stocks spooked by inflation fears
text: The market is in the grips of an inflation scare that's put a chokehold on growth stocks and it's been nightmare for tech, the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Market Shrugs Off Strong Retail Earnings
text: Earnings were hit hard by the Covid-19 pandemic, with each of the first three quarters of 2020 below the comparable quarters in 2019. The year-over-change was particularly dire in the June quarter when earnings for the S&P 500 index declined by almost a third from the year-earlier level.

title: Currency Valuation With Hard Assets In Place Of Inflation During QE
text: The dollar index based on hard assets is used to track the purchasing power of the dollar over time. Long-term treasury bonds are the canaries for the future debt crisis.

title: Coinbase Begins U.S. Direct Listing Rollout
text: Citigroup Inc said on Friday it recorded an additional $390 million in operating expenses in the 2020 fourth quarter after a U.S. federal judge ruled it was not entitled to recoup money it mistakenly wired to lenders of Revlon Inc last year.

title: What's Shaking The Stock Market?
text: Recent market turbulence has many worried, but Commonwealth CIO Brad McMillan says what's happening in the market actually makes sense.

title: Inflation Perfect Storm: The Fed's Dual Conundrum
text: Whether or not the stock market just peaked for the near-term of the next few months, one market move is very clear: interest rates and inflation are sharply on the rise.

title: SEC suspends trading in securities of 15 companies due to questionable practices
text: The SEC has suspended trading in securities of 15 companies due to questionable behavior and social media activity. This comes after many people tried to trade cheap stocks by inflating the price to gain profit.

text: The stock market ended mixed Friday, as the Nasdaq's rebound faded. Three leading stocks triggered sell signals during this week's sell-off.

text: Even for one investment veteran, the forced unwinding of popular trades among market participants this week was among the most violent in his career.

text: Prominent tech stocks including Microsoft, Intel, Apple, and Amazon ended with gains Friday despite a late drop in the three major U.S. indexes.

title: Wall Street ends on mixed footing as big tech outperforms the Dow
text: 4:10pm: Nasdaq rides tech gains to a positive close while S&P joins Dow under water The Dow Industrials closed Friday down 474 points, 1.5%, at 30,927. The Nasdaq managed to climb 73 points, 0.6%, to 13,192, while the S&P 500 slid 18 points, 0.5%, to 3,811.

title: 'Bloomberg Real Yield (02/26/2021)
text: Feb.26 -- Bloomberg's Jonathan Ferro hosts the return of Real Yield, with 30 minutes dedicated to fixed income. A round-table including TD Securites' Priya Misra, Bank of America's Mark Cabana and Zachary Swabe of UBS sit down to debate the tensions building in the bond market.

title: US investors were paid record dividends in 2020, study finds
text: US stock investors were paid a record amount of dividends in 2020, according to the latest edition of the Janus Henderson Global Dividend Index. Despite the global pandemic, US dividend payments climbed 2.6% to a record high of $503.1 billion last year. According to Janus Henderson data, just one in fourteen US companies cancelled its dividend between April and 2020 this year. Around the globe however, payouts were less positive. Dividend payments around the world fell to $1.26 trillion during 2020, a 12.2% decline, with the UK and Europe facing the most severe dividend cuts.

title: Joe Terranova: It's a lot harder to score goals in markets now
text: Joe Terranova, Virtus Investment Partners senior managing director, says sectors of the market that were down last year are likely to surge in 2021 as bond yields rise and stocks fall. He joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss whether he is changing his allocation in his portfolio after the shift in bond yields.

title: Dow ends around 475 points lower as Nasdaq bounces following worst fall since October
text: Stocks ended mostly lower Friday, dipping toward session lows in the final minutes of trading. Tech-related shares bounced after a rout sparked by a sharp rise in Treasury yields, but still suffered weekly losses.

title: Tech stocks rebound as bond-market turmoil and reflation trades fade
text: US stocks wavered on Friday as bonds pared some losses and investors moved back into defensive plays. The somewhat tepid session reverses several days of heavy selling in Treasurys that roiled the stock market. Yields soared to one-year highs as traders bet on new stimulus to lift inflation more than previously expected. The moves cut into growth stocks' appeal and fueled a sharp rotation to cyclical assets.

title: Rising interest rates may continue to test the stock market in the week ahead
text: The rapid rise in bond yields has made stocks skittish and that could be a factor in the week ahead.

title: The SEC suspends trading in 15 stocks because of suspicious activity and social-media chatter
text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission on Friday suspended trading in 15 companies because of "questionable trading and social media activity" as part of the agency's ongoing effort to prevent attempts to exploit investors, especially amid market volatility. "Today's action follows the recent suspensions of the securities of numerous other issuers, many of which may also have been targets of apparent social media attempts to artificially inflate their stock price," the official release said.

title: The pandemic could make lines at stores 'totally unacceptable,' says Qudini CEO Imogen Wethered
text: The pandemic may spell the end of lines at stores, Imogen Wethered, founder and CEO of Qudini, said at a retail roundtable hosted by Insider. "Retailers are going to have to work harder to implement new processes and digital ways of managing customers," Wethered said. "For us, hopefully, that means queues will be totally unacceptable, and digital ordering will be everywhere as well as in-store appointments. You'll be seeing contactless, curbside pick-up as well as virtual appointments."

title: Why the 'Queen of Small Caps' says it's still the time to be in them
text: Jill Carey Hall, BofA Global Research head of  U.S. small and mid-cap strategy, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss why she still favors small caps and the opportunities she's seeing in the market.

title: '10-Year Treasury Oversold ', BofA's Ciana Says

title: The Best Investment for the Next Five Years and Beyond
text: No one can know what will happen in the next five years and beyond. How can one know what stocks will be solid long-term investments?

title: Corn Futures Up-Trend Is Your Friend Until…?
text: New-crop December Corn futures (CZ21) have been on a historic run early in the 2021 calendar year. CZ21 traded up to a day high of $4.79 per bushel on February 25th with the current high close for the December contract coming a day earlier at $4.76 ¾.

title: Small caps, mid caps likely to outperform large caps, says UBS's Mike Ryan
text: Mike Ryan, UBS Global Wealth Management divisional vice chairman, joins 'Power Lunch' to discuss his perspective on the value vs. growth debate and if he is concerned about the rising interest rates.

title: It Wasn't Quite a 'Tantrum,' But Bond Markets Saw Ugly Trading This Week. Here's What It Means.
text: Even after yields fell Friday, the 10-year Treasury yield was still on track for a 12-basis-point weekly climb.
